description: 2020 JUN 05-- By a News Reporter-Staff News Editor at Pediatrics Daily News-- Current study results on Hematologic Diseases and Conditions- Sickle Cell Anemia have been published. Funders for this research include National Institute of Health, National Center for Advancing Translational Sciences, Emory and Children’ s Pediatric Seed Grant Program, National...
text:
2020 JUN 05 (NewsRx) -- By a News Reporter-Staff News Editor at Pediatrics
Daily News \-- Current study results on Hematologic Diseases and Conditions -
Sickle Cell Anemia have been published. According to news reporting
originating from Atlanta, Georgia, by NewsRx correspondents, research stated,
"This study aimed to: (1) examine changes in pain, psychosocial functioning,
and health care utilization among children and adolescents with sickle cell
disease (SCD) over a 2-year period and (2) identify baseline biopsychosocial
variables associated with the development and maintenance of chronic SCD pain
at follow-up. Forty-two youth (8 to 18 y old) with SCD completed a battery of
self-report measures at baseline and 2-year follow-up."

Funders for this research include National Institute of Health, National
Center for Advancing Translational Sciences (NCATS), Emory and Children's
Pediatric Seed Grant Program (Atlanta, GA), National Heart, Lung, and Blood
Institute (NHLBI) (Bethesda, MD).

Our news editors obtained a quote from the research from Emory University,
"Analgesic, Anesthetic, and Addiction Clinical Trial Translational Innovations
Opportunities and Networks and American Pain Society Pain Taxonomy (AAPT)
diagnostic criteria were used to categorize patients into pain frequency
groups at both timepoints: chronic (pain on most [>= 15] d/mo for the past 6
mo, per AAPT diagnostic criteria), episodic (pain on 1 to 14 d/mo), or
asymptomatic (0 d/mo). At baseline, 31% (n=13) had chronic pain, 50% (n=21)
episodic pain, and 19% (n=8) were asymptomatic. At follow-up, 40.5% (n=17) had
chronic pain, 52.4% (n=22) episodic pain, and 7.1% (n=3) were asymptomatic.
Between baseline and 2-year follow-up, 12% (n=5) developed chronic SCD pain.
Depressive symptoms and admissions for pain significantly increased over time
for youth with chronic pain (Ps <0.05). An interaction effect revealed that
baseline pain groups differed in their change in pain intensity over time (P
<0.01). Baseline psychosocial factors (ie, higher functional disability,
greater depressive symptoms, higher pain catastrophizing, and lower quality of
life) were significantly associated with chronic pain at follow-up."

According to the news editors, the research concluded: "Biopsychosocial
factors may be associated with the development and maintenance of chronic SCD
pain and their relative contributions warrant further study."

For more information on this research see: Changes In Pain and Psychosocial
Functioning and Transition To Chronic Pain In Pediatric Sickle Cell Disease a
Cohort Follow-up Study. _Clinical Journal of Pain_ , 2020;36(6):463-471.
_Clinical Journal of Pain_ can be contacted at: Lippincott Williams & Wilkins,
Two Commerce Sq, 2001 Market St, Philadelphia, PA 19103, USA.

The news editors report that additional information may be obtained by
contacting S. Sil, Emory University, Dept. of Pediatrics, School of Medicine,
Atlanta, GA 30322, United States. Additional authors for this research include
N. Bakshi, C. Dampier, L.L. Cohen, A. Watt, M. Hathaway and F. Abudulai.

The direct object identifier (DOI) for that additional information is:
<https://doi.org/10.1097/AJP.0000000000000827>. This DOI is a link to an
online electronic document that is either free or for purchase, and can be
your direct source for a journal article and its citation.

(Our reports deliver fact-based news of research and discoveries from around
the world.)

title: Researchers from Emory University Report New Studies and Findings in the Area of Sickle Cell Anemia (Changes In Pain and Psychosocial Functioning and Transition To Chronic Pain In Pediatric Sickle Cell Disease a Cohort Follow-up Study): Hematologic Diseases and Conditions - Sickle Cell Anemia
html:
2020 JUN 05 (NewsRx) -- By a News Reporter-Staff News Editor at Pediatrics Daily News -- Current study results on Hematologic Diseases and Conditions - Sickle Cell Anemia have been published. According to news reporting originating from Atlanta, Georgia, by NewsRx correspondents, research stated, “This study aimed to: (1) examine changes in pain, psychosocial functioning, and health care utilization among children and adolescents with sickle cell disease (SCD) over a 2-year period and (2) identify baseline biopsychosocial variables associated with the development and maintenance of chronic SCD pain at follow-up. Forty-two youth (8 to 18 y old) with SCD completed a battery of self-report measures at baseline and 2-year follow-up.”

Funders for this research include National Institute of Health, National Center for Advancing Translational Sciences (NCATS), Emory and Children’s Pediatric Seed Grant Program (Atlanta, GA), National Heart, Lung, and Blood Institute (NHLBI) (Bethesda, MD).

Our news editors obtained a quote from the research from Emory University, “Analgesic, Anesthetic, and Addiction Clinical Trial Translational Innovations Opportunities and Networks and American Pain Society Pain Taxonomy (AAPT) diagnostic criteria were used to categorize patients into pain frequency groups at both timepoints: chronic (pain on most [>= 15] d/mo for the past 6 mo, per AAPT diagnostic criteria), episodic (pain on 1 to 14 d/mo), or asymptomatic (0 d/mo). At baseline, 31% (n=13) had chronic pain, 50% (n=21) episodic pain, and 19% (n=8) were asymptomatic. At follow-up, 40.5% (n=17) had chronic pain, 52.4% (n=22) episodic pain, and 7.1% (n=3) were asymptomatic. Between baseline and 2-year follow-up, 12% (n=5) developed chronic SCD pain. Depressive symptoms and admissions for pain significantly increased over time for youth with chronic pain (Ps <0.05). An interaction effect revealed that baseline pain groups differed in their change in pain intensity over time (P <0.01). Baseline psychosocial factors (ie, higher functional disability, greater depressive symptoms, higher pain catastrophizing, and lower quality of life) were significantly associated with chronic pain at follow-up.”

According to the news editors, the research concluded: “Biopsychosocial factors may be associated with the development and maintenance of chronic SCD pain and their relative contributions warrant further study.”

For more information on this research see: Changes In Pain and Psychosocial Functioning and Transition To Chronic Pain In Pediatric Sickle Cell Disease a Cohort Follow-up Study. Clinical Journal of Pain, 2020;36(6):463-471. Clinical Journal of Pain can be contacted at: Lippincott Williams & Wilkins, Two Commerce Sq, 2001 Market St, Philadelphia, PA 19103, USA.

The news editors report that additional information may be obtained by contacting S. Sil, Emory University, Dept. of Pediatrics, School of Medicine, Atlanta, GA 30322, United States. Additional authors for this research include N. Bakshi, C. Dampier, L.L. Cohen, A. Watt, M. Hathaway and F. Abudulai.

The direct object identifier (DOI) for that additional information is: https://doi.org/10.1097/AJP.0000000000000827. This DOI is a link to an online electronic document that is either free or for purchase, and can be your direct source for a journal article and its citation.

(Our reports deliver fact-based news of research and discoveries from around the world.)
